# Bill of rights

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the concept. For the English law, see [Bill of Rights
1689](/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689 "Bill of Rights 1689"). For the United States
constitutional amendments, see [United States Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights").

"Charter of rights" redirects here. For the Canadian constitutional charter,
see [Canadian Charter of Rights and
Freedoms](/wiki/Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Canadian Charter of
Rights and Freedoms").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg/220px-
Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg)](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen_in_1789.jpg
"Enlarge")

The [Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the
Citizen](/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen
"Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen") of 1789 is a
fundamental document of the [French Revolution](/wiki/French_Revolution
"French Revolution") and in the history of [human rights](/wiki/Human_rights
"Human rights").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg/220px-
Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bill_of_Rights_Pg1of1_AC.jpg "Enlarge")

Draft of the [United States Bill of Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights
"United States Bill of Rights"), also from 1789

A **bill of rights** , sometimes called a _declaration of rights_ or a
_charter of rights_ , is a list of the most important [rights](/wiki/Rights
"Rights") to the citizens of a country. The purpose is to protect those rights
against [infringement from public officials and private
citizens](/wiki/Civil_and_political_rights "Civil and political rights"). The
term "bill of rights" originates from [England](/wiki/England "England"),
where it refers to the [Bill of Rights 1689](/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689 "Bill
of Rights 1689") enacted by Parliament following the [Glorious
Revolution](/wiki/Glorious_Revolution "Glorious Revolution"), asserting the
supremacy of Parliament over the monarch, and listing a number of fundamental
rights and liberties.

Bills of rights may be _[entrenched](/wiki/Entrenched_clause "Entrenched
clause")_ or _unentrenched_. An entrenched bill of rights cannot be modified
or repealed by a country's legislature through normal procedure, instead
requiring a supermajority or referendum; often it is part of a country's
constitution and therefore subject to special procedures applicable to
constitutional amendments. A _not entrenched_ bill of rights is a normal
[statute law](/wiki/Statute_law "Statute law") and as such can be modified or
repealed by the legislature at will.

In practice, not every jurisdiction enforces the protection of the rights
articulated in its bill of rights.

## List of bills of
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bill_of_rights&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: List of bills of rights")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/English_Bill_of_Rights_of_1689.jpg/220px-
English_Bill_of_Rights_of_1689.jpg)](/wiki/File:English_Bill_of_Rights_of_1689.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:English_Bill_of_Rights_of_1689.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Bill of Rights 1689](/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689 "Bill of Rights 1689") is
an Act of the [Parliament of England](/wiki/Parliament_of_England "Parliament
of England") asserting certain rights

### General[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bill_of_rights&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: General")]

  * [Magna Carta](/wiki/Magna_Carta "Magna Carta") (1215; England) rights for barons
  * [Great Charter of Ireland](/wiki/Great_Charter_of_Ireland "Great Charter of Ireland") (1216; Ireland) rights for barons
  * [Golden Bull of 1222](/wiki/Golden_Bull_of_1222 "Golden Bull of 1222") (1222; Hungary) rights for nobles
  * [Statute of Kalisz](/wiki/Statute_of_Kalisz "Statute of Kalisz") (1264; Kingdom of Poland) Jewish residents' rights
  * [Charter of Kortenberg](/wiki/Charter_of_Kortenberg "Charter of Kortenberg") (1312; Belgium) rights for all citizens "rich and poor"
  * [Dušan's Code](/wiki/Du%C5%A1an%27s_Code "Dušan's Code") (1349; Serbia)
  * [Twelve Articles](/wiki/Twelve_Articles "Twelve Articles") (1525; Germany)
  * [Pacta conventa](/wiki/Pacta_conventa_\(Poland\) "Pacta conventa \(Poland\)") (1573; Poland)
  * [Henrician Articles](/wiki/Henrician_Articles "Henrician Articles") (1573; Poland)
  * [Petition of Right](/wiki/Petition_of_Right "Petition of Right") (1628; England)
  * [Bill of Rights 1689](/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689 "Bill of Rights 1689") (England) and [Claim of Right Act 1689](/wiki/Claim_of_Right_Act_1689 "Claim of Right Act 1689") (Scotland) This applied to all British Colonies of the time, and was later entrenched in the laws of those colonies that became nations - for instance in Australia with the Colonial Laws Validity Act 1865 and reconfirmed by the [Statute of Westminster 1931](/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931 "Statute of Westminster 1931")
  * [Virginia Declaration of Rights](/wiki/Virginia_Declaration_of_Rights "Virginia Declaration of Rights") (June 1776)
  * Preamble to the [United States Declaration of Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States Declaration of Independence") (July 1776)
  * Chapter 1 of the [Pennsylvania Constitution](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Constitution_of_1776 "Pennsylvania Constitution of 1776") (July 1776)[1]
  * [Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen](/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_Man_and_of_the_Citizen "Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen") (1789; France)
  * [Bill of Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights") of the [United States Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution") (completed in 1789, ratified in 1791)
  * Declaration of the Rights of the People (1811; [Venezuela](/wiki/Venezuela "Venezuela"))
  * Article I of the [Constitution of Connecticut](/wiki/Constitution_of_Connecticut "Constitution of Connecticut") (1818)
  * [Constitution of Greece](/wiki/Constitution_of_Greece "Constitution of Greece") (1822; Epidaurus)
  * [Hatt-ı Hümayun](/wiki/Ottoman_Reform_Edict_of_1856 "Ottoman Reform Edict of 1856") (1856; Ottoman Empire)
  * Article I of the [Constitution of Texas](/wiki/Constitution_of_Texas "Constitution of Texas") (1875)
  * [Basic rights and liberties in Finland](/wiki/Constitution_of_Finland "Constitution of Finland") (1919)[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * [Articles 13-28](/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy#Civil_Relations_.28Articles_13-28.29 "Constitution of Italy") of the [Constitution of Italy](/wiki/Constitution_of_Italy "Constitution of Italy") (1947)
  * [Universal Declaration of Human Rights](/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights "Universal Declaration of Human Rights") (1948, United Nations)
  * [Fundamental rights and duties of citizens in People's Republic of China](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China "Constitution of the People's Republic of China") (1949)
  * [European Convention on Human Rights](/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights "European Convention on Human Rights") (1950)
  * [Fundamental Rights of Indian citizens](/wiki/Fundamental_Rights_of_Indian_citizens "Fundamental Rights of Indian citizens") (1950)
  * [Implied Bill of Rights](/wiki/Implied_Bill_of_Rights "Implied Bill of Rights") (a theory in [Canadian constitutional law](/wiki/Canadian_constitutional_law "Canadian constitutional law"))
  * [Canadian Bill of Rights](/wiki/Canadian_Bill_of_Rights "Canadian Bill of Rights") (1960)
  * [International Bill of Human Rights](/wiki/International_Bill_of_Human_Rights "International Bill of Human Rights") (1976)
  * [Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms](/wiki/Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms "Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms") (1982)
  * Article III of the [Constitution of the Philippines](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Philippines "Constitution of the Philippines") (1987)
  * Article 5 of the [Constitution of Brazil](/wiki/Constitution_of_Brazil "Constitution of Brazil") (1988)
  * [New Zealand Bill of Rights Act](/wiki/New_Zealand_Bill_of_Rights_Act "New Zealand Bill of Rights Act") (1990)
  * [Charter of Fundamental Rights and Basic Freedoms of the Czech Republic](/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_and_Basic_Freedoms "Charter of Fundamental Rights and Basic Freedoms") (1991)
  * [Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance](/wiki/Hong_Kong_Bill_of_Rights_Ordinance "Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance") (1991)
  * [Chapter 2 of the Constitution of South Africa](/wiki/Chapter_2_of_the_Constitution_of_South_Africa "Chapter 2 of the Constitution of South Africa") (entitled "Bill of Rights") (1996)
  * [Human Rights Act 1998](/wiki/Human_Rights_Act_1998 "Human Rights Act 1998") (United Kingdom)
  * [Human Rights Act 2004](/wiki/Human_Rights_Act_2004 "Human Rights Act 2004") (Australian Capital Territory)
  * [Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union](/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union "Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union") (2005)
  * [Victorian Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities](/wiki/Victorian_Charter_of_Human_Rights_and_Responsibilities "Victorian Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities") (2006; Australian state of Victoria)
  * Chapter Four of the [Constitution of Zimbabwe](/wiki/Constitution_of_Zimbabwe "Constitution of Zimbabwe") (2013)

  * [Gamer's Bill of Rights](/wiki/Gamer%27s_Bill_of_Rights "Gamer's Bill of Rights"), for video gamers
  * [Creator's Bill of Rights](/wiki/Creator%27s_Bill_of_Rights "Creator's Bill of Rights"), comic writers and artists
  * [Donor's Bill of Rights](/wiki/Donor%27s_Bill_of_Rights "Donor's Bill of Rights"), for philanthropic donors
  * [Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights](/wiki/Law_Enforcement_Officers%27_Bill_of_Rights "Law Enforcement Officers' Bill of Rights")
  * [California Voter Bill of Rights](/wiki/California_Voter_Bill_of_Rights "California Voter Bill of Rights"), adaptation of the [Voting Rights Act](/wiki/Voting_Rights_Act "Voting Rights Act")
  * [Islamic Bill of Rights for Women in the Mosque](/wiki/Islamic_Bill_of_Rights_for_Women_in_the_Mosque "Islamic Bill of Rights for Women in the Mosque")
  * [New Jersey Anti-Bullying Bill of Rights Act](/wiki/New_Jersey_Anti-Bullying_Bill_of_Rights_Act "New Jersey Anti-Bullying Bill of Rights Act")
  * Credit Cardholders' Bill of Rights, contained within the [Credit CARD Act of 2009](/wiki/Credit_CARD_Act_of_2009 "Credit CARD Act of 2009")
  * [Passengers' Bill of Rights](/w/index.php?title=Passengers%27_Bill_of_Rights&action=edit&redlink=1 "Passengers' Bill of Rights \(page does not exist\)")
  * Clone Bill of Rights, promoted by [Randy Wicker](/wiki/Randy_Wicker "Randy Wicker")'s Clone Rights United Front for [human cloning](/wiki/Human_cloning "Human cloning")

## Exceptions in Western
democracies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bill_of_rights&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Exceptions in Western democracies")]

[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") is the only common law country with
neither a constitutional nor federal legislative bill of rights to protect its
citizens, although there is ongoing debate in many of Australia's
states.[2][3] In 1973, Federal Attorney-General [Lionel
Murphy](/wiki/Lionel_Murphy "Lionel Murphy") introduced a human rights Bill
into parliament, although it was never passed.[4] In 1984, Senator [Stephen
Bunce](/wiki/Gareth_Evans_\(politician\) "Gareth Evans \(politician\)")
drafted a Bill of Rights, but it was never introduced into parliament, and in
1985, Senator [Lionel Bowen](/wiki/Lionel_Bowen "Lionel Bowen") introduced a
bill of rights, which was passed by the [House of
Representatives](/wiki/Australian_House_of_Representatives "Australian House
of Representatives"), but failed to pass the [Senate](/wiki/Australian_Senate
"Australian Senate").[5] Former [Australian Prime
Minister](/wiki/Australian_Prime_Minister "Australian Prime Minister") [John
Howard](/wiki/John_Howard "John Howard") has argued against a bill of rights
for Australia on the grounds it would transfer power from elected politicians
(populist politics) to unelected (constitutional) [judges](/wiki/Judge
"Judge") and [bureaucrats](/wiki/Bureaucrat "Bureaucrat").[6][7]
[Victoria](/wiki/Victoria_\(Australia\) "Victoria \(Australia\)") and the
[Australian Capital Territory](/wiki/Australian_Capital_Territory "Australian
Capital Territory") (ACT) are the only states and territories to have a human
rights Act.[8] [9] However, the principle of legality present in the
Australian judicial system, seeks to ensure that legislation is interpreted so
as not to interfere with basic human rights, unless legislation expressly
intends to interfere. [10]
